It‚Äôs good I suppose that bipolar is becoming more ‚Äúknown‚Äù, as you say... but I live in a country (UK) that never has adverts for these sorts of medications on tv or anywhere! The idea of it seems kinda strange to me - like we‚Äôre not out there as patients picking and choosing our meds on the basis of a strong advertising campaign?? That‚Äôs the job for our doctors who write prescriptions based on best medical evidence, not adverts. I dunno, different culture I guess. The only medicine adverts we have are for prescription-free stuff such as you might pick up in a supermarket, e.g. cough & cold syrups etc.
I agree, not an expert but it sounds more like BPD to me. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever come across lying as a trait that is strongly linked to bipolar...
My dog!! I couldn‚Äôt bear to think of abandoning him, and his presence also soothes me (just about the only thing that does tbh). Same as you though, I couldn‚Äôt do it to my family.
Yes, stay safe OP. I hope you get the help you need too.
Thank you, I needed this
Right now. Stay safe.

You can do it! I‚Äôve recently started up my gym membership again after being out of it for a year. I‚Äôm nowhere as fit as I was when I had it before, but I‚Äôm just going really easy when I go there and not expecting too much of myself. Like, even if it‚Äôs just 8 measly minutes walking on the treadmill and then I go home - who cares? The point is I made it down there even though my depression is really bad right now. But I‚Äôm starting to feel my fitness creeping back and that will lead me in itself to stay longer each time, so I‚Äôm trusting that gradually I‚Äôll get back to my original fitness level and it will become less of a chore. But with no pressure! All the best to you OP - you got this.

Already, the fact that you are willing to go the extra lengths to care for her and make it work in spite of the difficulties puts you waaay ahead of the game. Good on you. Sorry I know this isn‚Äôt advice as such... but just wanted to wish you all the best. You‚Äôre so lucky to have each other.
I have to keep telling myself not to get into ‚Äúwhataboutery‚Äù, but honestly, the exact same thought keeps popping into my head... It‚Äôs cynical, I know. But I can‚Äôt help it.
Same. So sorry you‚Äôre going through this, OP.
Totally random but I‚Äôm digging it. The un-blown-up balloon is my favourite.

Certainly the lows of BP2 reach as deep as those of BP1 - it‚Äôs the mania that BP1 has extreme. It‚Äôs a common misconception that BP1 is more severe than 2 though, when in actual fact they are just as bad each other. Just different manifestations of the same illness! 

At least, that‚Äôs my understanding anyway. You guys are totally right about the no monopoly on pain thing. The best thing we can do is be kind and support each other and not try to compare :)

Edit: I was thinking along the lines of the clinical criteria for BP1 & BP2, that clinicians don‚Äôt make a severity distinction between the two. In terms of our own personal sufferings, that‚Äôs a different matter, everyone‚Äôs individual on that front.
Thank you! Yes, if definitely helps even if it‚Äôs just a little. Hope you manage to get to the volunteering one day, but in the meantime well done for getting to work! High five right back at ya

I also went to work! Ok, so it wasn‚Äôt work (I‚Äôm still taking time off from a depressive episode) but actually a day‚Äôs volunteering I did for a local charity, but the point is I still made it out there in spite of the despair-fuelled wailing melt down I was having even as I walked out of the house. I was late, but I made it.
Brilliant, love it!!
Dalio! Just like everyone says, dalio is one of the best out there. This sub led me to it and I‚Äôm glad it did, it‚Äôs helping.
But thank god for dogs though, right? Don‚Äôt know how I‚Äôd get through this shit without mine.

Thank you, that was a nice response to my comment :) Yes, I‚Äôm still on the process of understanding myself, but it‚Äôs a long road! That we all have to go down; it‚Äôs good to know there are others here who share these experiences. I hope you get to see your trauma therapist soon and that it helps you.

I‚Äôve had what I believe are DP/DR episodes, which I‚Äôm pretty sure are related to an early adulthood trauma I went through (the same trauma that my psyc points to as a major factor in exacerbating my bipolar illness). I think maybe the DP/DR are like a kind of PTSD response? But I don‚Äôt know yet because I‚Äôm yet to talk properly to my therapist about it all, these aren‚Äôt symptoms that I‚Äôve fully recounted to my psychiatrist because it‚Äôs all been so difficult to talk about. But it‚Äôs on the table for my next therapy session. I don‚Äôt know if DP/DR is something that comes about just from having bipolar but it would make total sense, given how difficult and traumatic just having the illness in itself can be.
It‚Äôs tough isn‚Äôt it. Hang in there.
Cool work, well done!
Lovely
Awesome work, well done

Ohh sleep paralysis is the worst, I haven‚Äôt had it since I was a teenager though (now mid thirties). I did continue to get night terrors (spiders!!!) but they‚Äôve for the most part subsided now and I only get them occasionally and then I‚Äôd say they‚Äôre stress induced. Diagnosed BP2 and have been on lamotrigine 200mg for 4 years which has helped my sleep immensely (I guess by keeping the dark depressive episodes at bay).
I just watched Inside Out, with my hoodie hood up and a bar of Cadbury‚Äôs wholenut at my side. And my dog too, of course. Now melting into my cosy sofa and scrolling this sub.

Wow, that‚Äôs quite something! Hope you‚Äôre doing okay, hang in there. I like your activity entries on dalio by the way, I‚Äôm still adding to mine to try to cover all the things that might come up day to day.

Same here.

I don‚Äôt know about mania, but often when I‚Äôm depressed I can‚Äôt feel love, or for that matter any other emotion other than guilt, shame, etc. Like I know I love my family but I just can‚Äôt feel it. (Weirdly the only person I‚Äôm capable of loving in that headspace is my dog - does anyone else have experience of that? I definitely feel that animals can reach us in a special way when we fall into the darkness...) For me when I‚Äôm hypomanic, my emotions are heightened and my love for everyone feels much more overwhelming (in a good way).

I live in the UK and we have universal free health care in the form of the NHS. It‚Äôs wonderful and provides world class care when it works, but sadly the mental health provision is criminally underfunded and stretched to breaking point. This is even with politicians continually promising to give mental health extra funds and parity of esteem with physical. Among the worst of it is the waiting lists - I waited 18 months to see a psychiatrist one time. In the end I went private to finally get my diagnosis and treatment; I‚Äôm just fortunate I was in a financial position to be able to do that, but others aren‚Äôt so lucky.
Awesome

I love it! I wish I could do one like that of my dog!
It‚Äôs so pretty, what a lovely distraction to give yourself :)
Wow, that‚Äôs really comprehensive! Thank you so much for sharing!

I‚Äôve never been on carbamazepine but when i was mistakenly diagnosed with depression 10 years ago the doc put me on sertraline antidepressants that made my teeth grind like crazy. Painful as anything, and I felt even more awful than before. In the end I stopped the pills and it all made sense when I got my bipolar diagnosis some years later. Now on lamotrigine.
Wow that sounds like quite a ride! Glad you got the diagnosis though, hope you‚Äôre doing alright

So sorry you‚Äôre going through this. But it‚Äôs good that you have a psychiatrist who‚Äôs looking into your family history presumably so they can decide on the best course of treatment for you. If nothing else, you‚Äôre in a place where you are seeking help, and that in itself is an achievement. It takes a while to find the right meds so keep talking to your doctor about how your current ones make you feel and hopefully they can figure out something that might work better for you. Hopefully therapy is on the table too? Life with this illness can seem desperately bleak at times, but hang in there. You got this.

Will do! I don‚Äôt know so much about photography so it will be good to explore! 

Edit: I‚Äôm an art history grad so that‚Äôs why Hopper first came to my mind, him being a painter ;)

Hard to say but 2 or 3 months maybe? I don‚Äôt know, I find it so hard to tell when I‚Äôm hypo until after! I‚Äôm bp2 so have never had full mania - is it true that hypomania is usually considered to be shorter in duration than mania? I heard a couple of people say that recently but I didn‚Äôt think it was true??
Yes, talk to your doc! It wouldn‚Äôt hurt, as it does sound very hypo.
I‚Äôm on 200mg of lamictal and have been told by my psychiatrist that it‚Äôs considered a relatively low dose (bipolar type II)

Yes, BC decreasing the effect of lamotrigine is the way I‚Äôve heard it too. Best check with your doctor, op.

I‚Äôm sorry you had to hear such a thing. There‚Äôs sadly a lot of ignorance around suicide and the ‚Äúcry for help‚Äù interpretation is stupidly prevalent. Not that it‚Äôs your responsibility (or that of anyone suffering from bipolar, unless we choose to) to educate people, but perhaps talking and explaining to her what it was really about would help her understand and therefore be more sympathetic? Totally understand if you don‚Äôt want to, it‚Äôs your choice who you share things with and you should never feel you have to because you‚Äôve been backed into a corner. Either way, know that there are people here who understand and can stand with you in solidarity. There‚Äôs so much love and support on this sub, it blows my mind every time. Hope you‚Äôre okay.
